title: 459-D
statement: D. Pashmak and Parmida's problemtime limit per test3 secondsmemory limit per test256 megabytesinputstdinoutputstdoutParmida is a clever girl and she wants to participate in Olympiads this year. Of course she wants her partner to be clever too (although he's not)! Parmida has prepared the following test problem for Pashmak.There is a sequenceathat consists ofnintegersa1,a2, ...,an. Let's denotef(l,r,x)the number of indicesksuch that:l≤k≤randak=x. His task is to calculate the number of pairs of indiciesi,j(1 ≤i<j≤n)such thatf(1,i,ai) >f(j,n,aj).Help Pashmak with the test.InputThe first line of the input contains an integern(1 ≤n≤ 106). The second line containsnspace-separated integersa1,a2, ...,an(1 ≤ai≤ 109).OutputPrint a single integer — the answer to the problem.ExamplesInput71 2 1 1 2 2 1Output8Input31 1 1Output1Input51 2 3 4 5Output0

processed.result:
You are given a sequence of $n$ integers $a_1, a_2, ..., a_n$.  

Find the number of pairs of indices $(i, j)$ where $1 \le i < j \le n$ and the following condition is true:

There are more elements in the subarray $a_1, a_2, ..., a_i$ that equal $a_i$ than there are elements in the subarray $a_j, a_{j+1}, ..., a_n$ that equal $a_j$.  

In other words, you need to count the pairs $(i, j)$ such that:

 $$ \text{number of } k \text{ where } 1 \le k \le i \text{ and } a_k = a_i  > \text{number of } k \text{ where } j \le k \le n \text{ and } a_k = a_j $$ 



Let me know if you'd like help with the code to solve this problem!

Given a list of numbers, count how many pairs of positions in the list satisfy the condition: the number of times a specific number appears between the first position and the first position of the pair is greater than the number of times that same number appears between the second position and the end of the list.
